data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: Stephanie, the adopted daughter of Jim Cleland, becomes a restless spirit upon the death of her foster father and the concomitant departure of his son Jim, whom Stephanie has grown to love. Jim travels to Europe to complete his studies, and Stephanie is left in the care of attorney Grismer, the executor of Cleland's estate. Constantly in the presence of Grismer's son Oswald, Stephanie develops an affection for the boy, and one night, after circumstances force the two of them to spend the night in a roadhouse, Stephanie's reputation is so compromised that they decide to marry. After the ceremony, Stephanie realizes that she does not love her husband, and the two of them live apart. Jim returns from Europe, and Oswald, realizing Stephanie's great love for her foster brother, commits suicide so that Stephanie can marry the man she loves.
data.text:
A 30 May 1919 Variety news brief announced that Frances Marion had just finished writing the script for The Restless Sex, in which Marion Davies was attached to star. Frances Marion had just left a contract with Mary Pickford and was poised to sign a contract with William Randolph Hearst, the publishing mogul and film producer with whom Davies was romantically involved.

Principal photography began the week of 17 December 1919, as stated in that day’s New York Clipper. Production took place at the International Film Service Co.’s studio at 127th Street and Second Avenue in New York City. There, a number of sets, including a ballroom for the “Ball of the Gods” scene, were designed by Joseph Urban, according to the 13 September 1920 New York Times. In late January or early February 1920, the film company traveled to Florida to shoot exteriors in Miami and Palm Beach. The 14 February 1920 Motion Picture News announced the return of cast and crew to New York City.

A private screening was given in New York City on 2 June 1920. Prior to a general release on 31 October 1920, the picture premiered at the Criterion Theatre in New York on 12 September 1920. A review in the following day’s New York Times criticized the story as “long and complicated” and stated “Miss Davies does little in the way of acting, and Ralph Kellard and Carlyle Blackwell, as her heroes, do too much.” Nevertheless, The Restless Sex broke attendance records at the Criterion, and was booked in the theater for five weeks, as ...

More Less

A 30 May 1919 Variety news brief announced that Frances Marion had just finished writing the script for The Restless Sex, in which Marion Davies was attached to star. Frances Marion had just left a contract with Mary Pickford and was poised to sign a contract with William Randolph Hearst, the publishing mogul and film producer with whom Davies was romantically involved.

Principal photography began the week of 17 December 1919, as stated in that day’s New York Clipper. Production took place at the International Film Service Co.’s studio at 127th Street and Second Avenue in New York City. There, a number of sets, including a ballroom for the “Ball of the Gods” scene, were designed by Joseph Urban, according to the 13 September 1920 New York Times. In late January or early February 1920, the film company traveled to Florida to shoot exteriors in Miami and Palm Beach. The 14 February 1920 Motion Picture News announced the return of cast and crew to New York City.

A private screening was given in New York City on 2 June 1920. Prior to a general release on 31 October 1920, the picture premiered at the Criterion Theatre in New York on 12 September 1920. A review in the following day’s New York Times criticized the story as “long and complicated” and stated “Miss Davies does little in the way of acting, and Ralph Kellard and Carlyle Blackwell, as her heroes, do too much.” Nevertheless, The Restless Sex broke attendance records at the Criterion, and was booked in the theater for five weeks, as noted in a 9 October 1920 Wid’s Daily item.

In the film, Davies is seen dancing to a record played on a Columbia Grafanola phonograph. The 11 December 1920 Moving Picture World stated that when the scene was spotted by a Columbia executive, the company arranged for tie-in posters and lithographs that were provided “to all Columbia dealers in the Chicago territory.”

According to the Library of Congress American Silent Feature Film Survival Database, this film is extant.

Less

After the ceremony, Stephanie realizes that she does not love her husband, and the two of them live apart.
